Thus in a conflict between a great power with wide and varied interests and commitments and a small nation with the single objective of survival, the balance of forces cannot always be calculated by simple arithmetic. (p XVII)

Finns learned about ideological solidarity in 1939. Even Marshal Gustav Mannerheim, a man unusually free of sentimentality, was moved to declare at the end of the Winter War, "We have paid our debt to the West to the last drop of blood."

p XXIII

From the ruins of the tsar's empire Finland emerged in 1917 as a sovereign state, and Lenin's government was the first to recognize it. No doubt in hope that an extension of Bolshevik Revolution into Finland would bring back to the Soviet Union what had been lost by Russia

p15

In the Anglo French vocabulary, the term (‚ÄúBaltic states‚Äù) referred exclusively to Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, while Finland was included among the Scandinavian states.

On Russian maps, Finland too was a Baltic state.

p44

Winston Churchill later wrote in his memoirs that Russia's neighbors "could not make up their minds which to fear more German aggression or Soviet protection." ‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ In reality at least Finland and the Baltic states had no difficulty in making up their minds; they had no fear of German aggression, while Soviet protection seemed to them the gravest threat to their independence.

p71

There is a permanent Finnish-Russian agenda, and it has only one item: how to reconcile the stubborn Finnish will to independence with the Great Power ambitions of Russia?

The Swedish government was treating Finland the way a man might treat a mistress whom he wishes to discard as gently as possible. (In september 1939)

the speech by the delegate from Leningrad at the Supreme Soviet had struck an ominous note. "From whom does Finland hope to get help?" he had asked. "Poland, too, had a guarantee. . ."

As the Finns were leaving [Nov 3, 1939], Molotov said cryptically, ‚ÄúWe civilians don't seem to be making progress; now it is the soldiers' turn to speak." It was the closest to a threat of force he ever uttered throughout the talks.

In retrospect, it seems insanely illogical that the military precautions that had been thought necessary at the beginning of the negotiations were relaxed the moment the negotiations had ended in failure.

But [British Minister] Snow succeeded only in making himself un popular in Helsinki and had to be recalled soon after the war broke out, presumably as a penalty for having been right.

[in November 1939 Marshall Mannerheim] clearly favored further concessions rather than risking a war that could only end in disaster; even giving up Hanko was in his opinion "unpleasant rather than deadly."

"In three days it will be all over," Soviet diplomats in Berlin told William Shirer, the American correspondent.

Advance units of the Red Army were even warned not to cross by mistake the Swedish border.

p168

For the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic could not wage a conventional, bourgeois war against another or another nation. It had never waged such a war‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶The invasion of Finland also had to be justified in the face of Marx and Lenin; the bombs dropped on Helsinki had to have an ideologically acceptable address. p168

In December 1939 the superiority of the Soviet forces advancing into Finland from four directions was indeed overwhelming.

Nine Finnish divisions, with 14,000 men in each, faced four Soviet armies, altogether about half a million men

p172

In the Western world, Finland's fight was written off in advance as no more than an heroic gesture, a romantic act of defiance, a reckless refusal to face the cold facts of modern warfare, or simply national suicide.

p173

The first month of fighting had shown the Soviet war machine to be clumsy and inept. All along the lengthy front it had either broken down completely or at least been brought to a standstill.

p174

He [Holsti] did it brilliantly, insofar as the obvious can ever be brilliantly stated. No one actually needed to be convinced; even the most loyal supporters of the Soviet Union found it hard to justify the invasion of Finland as an act of self-defense.

p178

Finns were disappointed in Sweden, angry with Germany.

p184

From his [Mussolini] point of view, therefore, Finland was fighting a delaying action that kept Soviet power tied up in the North; every day that the Finns held out was a day gained on the Balkan front [Bessarabia].

p188

Hitler was convinced that "Russia never intended to make up this fight, for otherwise she would have chosen a different season." For this reason it was unfair, he thought, to criticize her military effort

On paper, the French design looked like a grand pincer movement of continental scope-from the Arctic to the Black Sea.

according to Marshal Mannerheim's estimate, almost half of the regular divisions normally stationed in Europe and western Siberia were engaged against Finland.

Thus the effects of the Winter War were being felt far and wide throughout the Soviet Union.

Suomussalmi. Siilasvuo. Raate Road.

Three-quarters of a century later, those names still carry mythological weight in Finland, and with good reason.

Unquestionably, the destruction of the 163rd Division at Suomussalmi, and the subsequent decimation of the highly regarded 44th Division at Raate Road by the outnumbered, out-equipped Finnish forces led by Colonel Hjalmar Siilasvuo, ‚Ä¶

ranks as one of modern Finland's proudest moments, as well as a classic military double victory with few if any precedents in the history of modern warfare.

p187

The Russians seemed to be more put out by the loss of the equipment than that of their men: Moscow Radio announced that if the Finns didn't return the Soviet equipment they recovered at Suomussalmi and Raate, the Kremlin would declare war on Finland!
